rev.diff:
Line 47: Line 47:
=== Police brutality ===
=== Police brutality ===
â
A leaked US embassy cable from 2009 described [[police brutality]], including [[torture]], as common and pervasive, and the government's efforts to combat it as ineffective and lacking in political will.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/us-embassy-cables-documents/187359 |title=US embassy cables: Police brutality in Egypt |publisher=Guardian |data2011-01-28 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> The [[Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights]] has documented 567 cases of torture, including 167 deaths, by police that occurred between 1993 and 2007.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6943704.stm |title=Egypt police sued for boy's death |publisher=BBC News |date=2007-08-13 |accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref> On 6 June 2010 [[Khaled Mohamed Saeed]] died under disputed circumstances in the [[Sidi Gaber]] area of [[Alexandria]]. Multiple witnesses testified that Saeed was beaten to death by the police.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/anger-alexandria-we%E2%80%99re-afraid-our-own-government|title=Anger in Alexandria: 'Weâre afraid of our own government' |publisher=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=2010-06-25|accessdate=2010-07-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Two witnesses affirm Alex victim beaten by police |author= |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/two-witnesses-affirm-alex-victim-beaten-police |newspaper=[[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=June 19, 2010 |accessdate=January 26, 2011}}</ref>
+
A leaked US embassy cable from 2009 described [[police brutality]], including [[torture]], as common and pervasive, and the government's efforts to combat it as ineffective and lacking in political will.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/us-embassy-cables-documents/187359 |title=US embassy cables: Police brutality in Egypt |publisher=Guardian |data2011-01-28 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> The [[Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights]] has documented 567 cases of torture, including 167 deaths, by police that occurred between 1993 and 2007.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6943704.stm |title=Egypt police sued for boy's death |publisher=BBC News |date=2007-08-13 |accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref> On 6 June 2010 [[Khaled Mohamed Saeed]] died under disputed circumstances in the [[Sidi Gaber]] area of [[Alexandria]]. Multiple witnesses testified that Saeed was beaten to death by the police.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/anger-alexandria-we%E2%80%99re-afraid-our-own-government|title=Anger in Alexandria: 'Weâre afraid of our own government' |publisher=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=2010-06-25|accessdate=2010-07-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Two witnesses affirm Alex victim beaten by police |author= |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/two-witnesses-affirm-alex-victim-beaten-police |newspaper=[[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=June 19, 2010 |accessdate=January 26, 2011}}</ref> [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], led a rally in Alexandria against alleged abuses by the police and visited Saeed's family to offer condolences.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201062642955204618.html|title=ElBaradei leads anti-torture rally|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=26 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref>
  +
[[File:Day of Anger marchers.jpg|thumb|Marching protesters on 25 January]]
=== Economic climate===
=== Economic climate===
Line 68: Line 68:
A policeman was reported to have died in Cairo, while in Suez two protesters died.<ref name="bbc25jan"/> In Cairo, police forces used tear gas and water cannons against the protesters, who in turn threw stones at police, eventually forcing them to retreat.<ref name="bbc25jan">{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12272836 | title=Egypt protests: Three killed in 'day of revolt' | accessdate=26 January 2011 | date=25 January 2011 | work=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> It has been reported that many police had been restrained in the use of violence. One policeman was quoted to have said to a protester that he had only three months of duty left and after that "I'll be on the other side of the barricade."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70O2GG20110125?sp=true |title=Q+A-How will Egypt's protests affect Mubarak's rule?|publisher=Reuters |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
A policeman was reported to have died in Cairo, while in Suez two protesters died.<ref name="bbc25jan"/> In Cairo, police forces used tear gas and water cannons against the protesters, who in turn threw stones at police, eventually forcing them to retreat.<ref name="bbc25jan">{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12272836 | title=Egypt protests: Three killed in 'day of revolt' | accessdate=26 January 2011 | date=25 January 2011 | work=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> It has been reported that many police had been restrained in the use of violence. One policeman was quoted to have said to a protester that he had only three months of duty left and after that "I'll be on the other side of the barricade."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70O2GG20110125?sp=true |title=Q+A-How will Egypt's protests affect Mubarak's rule?|publisher=Reuters |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
â   â
[[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], led a rally in Alexandria against alleged abuses by the police and visited Saeed's family to offer condolences.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201062642955204618.html|title=ElBaradei leads anti-torture rally|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=26 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref>
  â
